number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Spintires is an off-road simulator. It's a very niche genre without a whole lot of competition. In fact, the only game you can compare Spintires to on Steam is probably "Off-Road Drive", which is also a great game. As an avid off-roader IRL (as they say), I can attest to this game's ability to scratch that off-roading itch a little bit. Only the real thing is better. The mud and water deformation is amazing (an apparently, award winning). The physics of driving a vehicle off-road is as close to the real thing as I've ever seen in a video game; there is no going fast in this game. The fastest you can go is maybe 20 MPH if you find some paved road (which is rare) and shift it into high gear. Ostensibly, the game is about logging. More accurately, hauling lumber through the Russian backwoods.  That's it, haul lumber from point A to point B, alone or with a "crew" of up to 4. Of course, you could just ignore all that and just go hit the trails, which is also really fun. That said, this game isn't for everyone. My wife watched as, for 15 minutes, a buddy and I struggled, trial-and-errored and fought a piece of terrain which was only about 10 feet long. Let me be clear: 15 minutes to go 10 feet. She couldn't understand the appeal of that, and I can totally understand why many would be turned off by it. But you know, THAT IS OFF-ROADING. That's how it goes down in a real life, sometimes even longer to go an even shorter distance! But off-roaders live for that sort of thing. I absolutely love the technical ability and intestinal fotitude needed to tackle terrain like that. By the way, the winching system is stellar! Since the game is so good at capturing that, this is not an easy game. On top of the technical challenge of maneuvering an 8x8 monstrosity towing a trailer full of long logs through tight slush, your truck has both limited fuel and hit points. Yeah, here comes the pain.There are cons however, ones that luckily can be remedied fairly easily. - The damage model is inconsistent and frankly a bit harsh. I'll be driving my little UAZ 4x4 in some gummy muck, hit a rock a bit larger than my vehicle likes, take it right in the undercarriage and I'll do about 1-7 hit points of damage. Then I'll hit a tree barely any larger than a sapling with my front bumper going slower than when I hit the aforementioned rock and cause 25-55 points of damage! Quite a bit when you have 200 HP. This damage model also COMPLETELY negates using 4WD high; when you find a bumpy but solid road, not a whole lot of mud, you'll be tempted to put it in high to get a little more speed. WELL DON'T. Those tiny little bumps will start hitting you for 10, 15, 25, 50 or more hit points even if you're hitting them with your tires. Found a paved road? Think it's time to shift it into high gear? WRONG. I tried this with on of the big hauler trucks, gathered a decent amount of speed, hit a dip and BAM! 200+ damage in one hit! Why am I being punished for driving 25 MPH on a paved road? I don't get the logic there. I'm not sure what this is supposed to be simulating. Maybe these Russian trucks are made of glass?- The maps. There about 5 or so maps and they are quite large and can take quite a while to explore. However, let's be honest Spintires fans, they're all the same. Yes, some have more water than others, one even has a volcano, but at the end of the day you're spending about 80% of the time driving (and getting stuck in) mud, 10% in water, 5% in dirt and 5% on rocks and other rough terrain. The majority of these maps are covered in impassible forest, with trees so close to each other there's no way to squeeze between them. Also, all too often the terrain texture is grass or dirt, then when you drive on it, it ends up being mud. Deep, gummy, unforgiving mud.  - I don't understand why there isn't an official sandbox mode. It seems to fit this game perfectly. The logging and hauling is great. Tons of fun. A great challenge. But sometimes I just want it to drop me on a map, infinite fuel, damage turned off, let me choose ANY truck in the game and just let me GO, with friends too!- Excuse my language, and I'm sorry if this offends anyone, but the only trucks in the game are Russian sh*tboxes. Gutless wonders, every last of 'em. I don't know if licensing Jeeps, Toyotas and Land Rovers was too expensive or what, but we need something different. Even the big diesel trucks feel way too large and heavy for the amount of power they have, which is probably what it's actually like in the real world. The UAZ is a tiny Jeep imitation, it doesn't need much power, but they give it to you with placid, pizza cutter tires. Imagine taking THAT in the mud. Yeah, you get real cozy with your winch. Broncos, Blazers, Hiluxes, CJs, Wranglers, Patrols, FJ40s... gimmie gimmie gimmie!Finally, this game was born to be modded and has a large and healthy modding community. It's just a matter of time before all of the above gripes are addressed (Workshop integration would be amazing!) So for now, this game is great, but given time, Spintires will become the greatest off-road sim of all time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I thought this game was a joke when I first saw it appear on Steam. Driving trucks through the mud for $30? Pfft! Get out of here.Then I tried the tech demo and was instantly hooked.This game has a lot to offer if you're looking to be entertained. There aren't really any objectives, but the maps are interesting to explore and the physics are hilariously fun. Who knew Russian logging could be so interesting?Pros:-Surprisingly good graphics-Deformable terrain and off-roading goodness-WINCHES-Varied and useful "attachments" that can be loaded onto your vehicle at a garage-There is a considerable challenge in just navigating the terrain, from towing a log trailer through deep muck to navigating river crossings that can easily flood your engine or tip you over-Multiplayer! -Heavy modding community presence-Terrain remains deformed between saving and loading your save back up. You can create trouble spots for yourself if you're not careful.-Refreshing gameplay, who else has made an offroad simulator even close to this?Mixed:- Camera is extremely robust, the developer knew players would need to see their vehicles from all kinds of wonky angles. This also makes the camera difficult to control/learn to use, however.- You can only control 1st and 2nd gears along with reverse. In order to reach gears 3+ you must shift into "automatic" meaning the subsequent shifts aren't under your control. This can be a problem, if say, you wanted to cruise along the road at the speed offered by 3rd gear but the transmission shifts itself to 4th and continues accelerating.- Wooded areas can be too dense. You may want to take a shortcut through some trees to avoid a muddy area you know you aren't able to surpass, but oftentimes you can't because the spacing between trees is too tight for your vehicle. This makes it VERY easy to trap yourself in a cluster of trees, especially on an incline.Bad:- Lack of objectives can be a turn-off for many players- Small selection of vehicles (though there are dozens available with mods) and they are strictly Russian.- Very narrow focus (Russian logging) which could easily have been expanded to other areas of the globe.- No independent saves. If you want to switch maps you must delete the save for the previous map you were on. It really makes no sense why the developer chose to do this.- There are some graphical glitches here and there, though nothing too serious- Random bugs. None that are game-breaking, but they can be annoying

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												After playing only a few hours of this game, I've found that I'm absolutely terrible at driving UAZs off-road. However, my spectacular failures were made hilariously fun by this game.As probably the most in-depth off-road simulation game I've ever played (and the only one at that) this game is incredibly good fun, even in the early stages. Now, whereas I'd love to see more challenges and other tasks I think that this game is definetely worth the buy.So take it from me. If you want to drive all manner of old Russian vehicles and potentially end up stuck in the mud, get this game and winch your backside out of it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												A powerful message is inside: those trucks guzzle fuel, and pollute. Nature fights back with demonic mud, hidden rocks, trees between you and your goal! Jokes aside, this game is quite fun, but you should try the old demo before purchasing it, because everything is SO slow, that it might indeed not be for everybody. Also the camera is... ugh. Looks awesome, shows the truck and the road. The moment you need to see in front of you however, there is no way! It's always on the side, and it shows the road ahead nicely. Usually. Get between a few trees however, and you'll bump into a tree that was invisible. Drive at night down a small road with trees on the side, and you'll get to watch everything through the trees. Really, a camera on the hood would help a lot. You can wrestle that camera around, but it's easily the part that they need to improve of the whole game. That said controls are good, graphically it's not epic but looks good, and it has nice attention to detail like getting mud/water on the trucks in the correct places. Audio... engines sound nice, but nothing special. Also it like to lower the volume every time I start it, for some reason.Anyway, I really like this, and can only imagine how much more fun it would be with a friend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Spintires is an off-road simulator. It's a very niche genre without a whole lot of competition. In fact, the only game you can compare Spintires to on Steam is probably "Off-Road Drive", which is also a great game. As an avid off-roader IRL (as they say), I can attest to this game's ability to scratch that off-roading itch a little bit. Only the real thing is better. The mud and water deformation is amazing (an apparently, award winning). The physics of driving a vehicle off-road is as close to the real thing as I've ever seen in a video game; there is no going fast in this game. The fastest you can go is maybe 20 MPH if you find some paved road (which is rare) and shift it into high gear. Ostensibly, the game is about logging. More accurately, hauling lumber through the Russian backwoods.  That's it, haul lumber from point A to point B, alone or with a "crew" of up to 4. Of course, you could just ignore all that and just go hit the trails, which is also really fun. That said, this game isn't for everyone. My wife watched as, for 15 minutes, a buddy and I struggled, trial-and-errored and fought a piece of terrain which was only about 10 feet long. Let me be clear: 15 minutes to go 10 feet. She couldn't understand the appeal of that, and I can totally understand why many would be turned off by it. But you know, THAT IS OFF-ROADING. That's how it goes down in a real life, sometimes even longer to go an even shorter distance! But off-roaders live for that sort of thing. I absolutely love the technical ability and intestinal fotitude needed to tackle terrain like that. By the way, the winching system is stellar! Since the game is so good at capturing that, this is not an easy game. On top of the technical challenge of maneuvering an 8x8 monstrosity towing a trailer full of long logs through tight slush, your truck has both limited fuel and hit points. Yeah, here comes the pain.There are cons however, ones that luckily can be remedied fairly easily. - The damage model is inconsistent and frankly a bit harsh. I'll be driving my little UAZ 4x4 in some gummy muck, hit a rock a bit larger than my vehicle likes, take it right in the undercarriage and I'll do about 1-7 hit points of damage. Then I'll hit a tree barely any larger than a sapling with my front bumper going slower than when I hit the aforementioned rock and cause 25-55 points of damage! Quite a bit when you have 200 HP. This damage model also COMPLETELY negates using 4WD high; when you find a bumpy but solid road, not a whole lot of mud, you'll be tempted to put it in high to get a little more speed. WELL DON'T. Those tiny little bumps will start hitting you for 10, 15, 25, 50 or more hit points even if you're hitting them with your tires. Found a paved road? Think it's time to shift it into high gear? WRONG. I tried this with on of the big hauler trucks, gathered a decent amount of speed, hit a dip and BAM! 200+ damage in one hit! Why am I being punished for driving 25 MPH on a paved road? I don't get the logic there. I'm not sure what this is supposed to be simulating. Maybe these Russian trucks are made of glass?- The maps. There about 5 or so maps and they are quite large and can take quite a while to explore. However, let's be honest Spintires fans, they're all the same. Yes, some have more water than others, one even has a volcano, but at the end of the day you're spending about 80% of the time driving (and getting stuck in) mud, 10% in water, 5% in dirt and 5% on rocks and other rough terrain. The majority of these maps are covered in impassible forest, with trees so close to each other there's no way to squeeze between them. Also, all too often the terrain texture is grass or dirt, then when you drive on it, it ends up being mud. Deep, gummy, unforgiving mud.  - I don't understand why there isn't an official sandbox mode. It seems to fit this game perfectly. The logging and hauling is great. Tons of fun. A great challenge. But sometimes I just want it to drop me on a map, infinite fuel, damage turned off, let me choose ANY truck in the game and just let me GO, with friends too!- Excuse my language, and I'm sorry if this offends anyone, but the only trucks in the game are Russian sh*tboxes. Gutless wonders, every last of 'em. I don't know if licensing Jeeps, Toyotas and Land Rovers was too expensive or what, but we need something different. Even the big diesel trucks feel way too large and heavy for the amount of power they have, which is probably what it's actually like in the real world. The UAZ is a tiny Jeep imitation, it doesn't need much power, but they give it to you with placid, pizza cutter tires. Imagine taking THAT in the mud. Yeah, you get real cozy with your winch. Broncos, Blazers, Hiluxes, CJs, Wranglers, Patrols, FJ40s... gimmie gimmie gimmie!Finally, this game was born to be modded and has a large and healthy modding community. It's just a matter of time before all of the above gripes are addressed (Workshop integration would be amazing!) So for now, this game is great, but given time, Spintires will become the greatest off-road sim of all time.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Fantastic off road simulation. Gorgeous wilderness, impressive mud physics, and the vehicles have a great sense of mass and power with the way they handle. It's one of those games where there are goals, but the game doesn't hold your hand or guide you. It's up to you to set objectives, choose your paths and get it done. It can be frustrating considering the pace you have to take in order to avoid mishaps, but it's worth a look if you want to drive huge Soviet-era trucks through Crytech-rendered forests.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												*I play with a Logitech G27 Wheel and have only played singleplayer (so far)*I love this game. I don't really know why, but I do. I'm not a gear head or car guy by any means, but I got crazy into a racing game that led to me buying a G27 wheel. All I end up playing is Spintires though! I'm hooked. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, but it gives you all the pieces to do what you want. Beyond the objective of delivering lumber there is no right or wrong way to play Spintires, just your way. A playthrough of a map consists of some basic concepts;-You start with certain vehicle(s) at a checkpoint of a “garage”. Vehicles can take damage and they burn fuel that needs refilling.-A garage lets you change the attachments your vehicle has. In general they are attachments to carry garage parts, repair parts, log carriers, or fuel. But each vehicle's attachment options vary.-Each map has other garage locations that can be unlocked by delivering garage parts. Fueling stations for refueling vehicles and fuel carrying attachments. Lumber pickup areas where lumber has been cut down. And finally the objective areas where you are suppose to deliver the lumber to.And that's it. It's a simple game. You have to pickup and deliver a few loads of logs to one or more specified locations on a map. Simple! But... Not actually so simple. The terrain will make that a monumental undertaking. Mud mud and more mud! Hills, rocks, woods, raging rivers, open water, and more all are there to ruin your vehicle and day. It isn't a matter of IF you will get stuck or rollover its a matter of WHEN. And if it isn't the environs that get you, it'll be yourself. Progress is very slow and steady and can lull you in to a false sense of security. An hour or two of mistake free trudging in first gear and you get lazy and you make a mistake. A bad  turn, hit an object, try to cut a corner or cross a river at the wrong spot, take on deeper mud than you should with a heavier load, etc etc. You'll make mistakes no doubt. Throw in some strategic planning with which vehicles(s) you use for what and some side objectives/exploring... And you got yourself buried neck deep in the mud both literally and figuratively! But you aren't on your own out there. The vehicles and their attachments keep you movin'. And with winches on every vehicle as long as you're near some trees or can get a second vehicle close you got a chance to get unstuck or right-side-up again. I am constantly amazed at what I can get myself in to, and out of, in this game. And boy is there so so so many ways to get stuck, but just as many inventive ways to get out. "Where there's a will there's a way". You can spend hours just getting out of a mess you could have avoided in the first place. But somehow you end up not caring. As of writing this review I have completed 4 of the (currently) 6 stock maps on “hardcore” and they've taken me 3.5 to 6hrs a piece thanks to the messes you invariably get in to. Pros:-Difficult but completely fair.-A million mistakes to make and a million ways out of each one.-Runs at 60fps 1080p 100% of the time on my FX 6300/R9 270 toaster.-Fun as *blank* with G27!Things you will have to overcome:-The difficulty and your patience.-The camera angles seem annoying and “wrong” at first but ultimately make sense for the visual information you need when trudging through the mud. And you get used to them quickly. But the optional mouse movement to swing the camera around is fairly clunky. Also no “cockpit” camera as of writing this which means using a wheel in “third person” 99% of the time. There is a “hood” camera for tight corners. But like I said, the default view ultimately makes sense in the end. You see everything you NEED to from that angle, especially the tires' positions. -!!!Using a racing wheel like the G27 will not absolve you from still needing to use the mouse (and possibly keyboard)!!! Not all controls can be bound within the game but I used the Logitech Profiler software to bind keystrokes to buttons to eliminate my need for the keyboard 100%. There are crane controls for loading logs in “hardcore” mode that needs 9 buttons on its own. Without doing it my way you would still need to control that crane on the keyboard as well as some other controls. Then mouse will control menus, winch hookup placement, and manual looking around no matter what. So you WILL need your mouse no matter what. Not an issue with my desk setup but I know some people have “cockpits” for their wheels that don't accommodate a mouse and keyboard. So fair warning there!Cons:-Saving system is so-so. Its automatic and works fine. But twice I had save files corrupt when I Windows-key'd to minimize then re-maximized. Nothing tragic but the potential is there with how grueling a map can be. I can't imagine being 4hrs in and losing a save. I'd cry. And some on the forums have complained of losing in progress saves when the game has updated. I haven't needed it, but saves are in C:/Users/”your username”/AppDate/Roaming/SpinTires/UserSaves and if I exit in the middle of a long game I manually backup the file somewhere out of fear. But I have never had to use my backup. -Weird community. I guess there was lots promised for the game that the long time players still want. But there was a long stall in the updates or something. Then the current updates aren't coming fast enough for the community or something. You'll notice a lot of the “negative” reviews are people that actually like the game but are mad with the developers. Its unfair of me to judge being a fresh face but the community has been pure cynicism and impatience in my experiences so far. Which has kept me from prodding towards MP.The game is a great unique experience and words cannot explain it. I can't imagine keyboard and mouse controls being that much less of a great experience as a wheel. Because the game is just plain fun. But again this review is written by someone using a wheel. Which has been a great experience. The regular price is a bit steep but there are sales to be had. I personally got it in a bundle and that was an absolute steal. As of writing this the game is still being updated and worked on by the developer which is nice, always appreciate more! Supposedly Steam Workshop is coming which would be pretty neat. I guess a mod community already exists out on the web. Also, the MP looks like loads and loads of fun as well. But the stock, vanilla game is keeping me plenty busy for now and makes the game worth it on it's own. I am not a modern multitasker but this game lends itself well to watching TV/movies during it. Or having a phone/Skype convo during it. Very casual and methodical. But like I mentioned, don't get too distracted and lulled in to that false sense of security... You'll be spinning tires in the mud and cursing the heavens in no time! Enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												one of the finest off road games made to date, level of detail is awesome, the way the tyres deform according to terrain, the way the vehicles respond to the enviroment and the way the terrain responds back. All really really well done. Sadly as a result some things have suffered. Primarily the camera view! my god its shockingly bad, Its as if the guy who was in charge of the tyre animation was in charge. If you want a nice side profile of your truck then the camera will oblige, You get some lovely shots of the 8 wheeler smashing through the woods, Right up to the point it throws itself down a cliff upside down into a river. ask it for a forwards view and it fights you all the way, Twitching from one side to another, or getting too close to the truck when you search vainly for a better angle. SORT IT OUT! Next is the winch interface, This need refining as there are too many button presses and mouse clicks to perform smooth winching when required (oh and a few more yards of cable wouldnt hurt ya tight gits!) Last but not least is all the vehicles appear to be made of glass or paper mache as they damage far too easily. That said it is still a game I readily chucked 20 quid at, And if the mods available for the tech demo are anything to go by then it will shape up to be an awesome community created game when they get round to releasing mod support

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												I'm having a lot of fun with this game. The challenge is high, especially in single-player mode. This game is not for light-sim players or casual players. It takes time, skill, and patience to succeed. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging sim. Multiplayer is only slightly easier, since you have others to help you out of any situation you find yourself in. The only problem I have seen so far is the lack of multiplayer searches. I can find one or two games, but none of them speaks English. That's fine, except that they will kick you from their server, and you're stuck doing single player. If there was a broader multiplayer search, or a way to set to a specific language, it would be spot on.Highly recommend game! Very enjoyable!

												So at the time I originally posted this review, it had been because of issues with the game's source code that rendered it unplayable.  According to some people, this was a result of a dispute between the game's developer and its publisher, while the dev claimed it was tied into an anti-piracy system he'd implemented.  So if anyone who commented or anything wanted a reason for me switching it from not recommended to recommended, there you go.Whichever of those was true, that issue's been patched.  Instead, I can now say that Spintires is a genuinely fun game, particularly if you've got other people playing it with you.  There isn't really anything else like this out there, that I've seen, and I genuinely can't recommend it enough now that it's back up and running.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Spintires has the worst user interfaces I have seen in a video game in many years.  The camera control is infuriating, you have to put your controller down to reach for a keyboard way too often, multiplayer requires rock solid 50mb/s monster connections to work, it milked the early access program in a sketchy way, and vehicle handling is rudimentary at best.  Yet, it is a phenomenally fun game.Though It is difficult to explain why this game is fun, it sure is.  You are basically tasked with moving a handful of logs from one camp to another.  In so doing, you will have to unlock the map to reveal potential routes and collect usable vehicles.  Each vehicle has different strengths and weaknesses, leading to the real meat of the game: logistics.  Garages, where vehicles can be repaired or outfitted with different accessories (trailers, fuel storage, repair tools, etc), must be unlocked by hauling special loads to them.  Some of the heavier trucks will require support tankers or detours to fuel depots in order to reach their destinations.  The task of actually driving the trucks through the absolutely gorgeous, photo-realistic scenery is actually secondary to the game experience, which is why so many of the game's faults are tolerable.  It isn't a driving game so much as it's a logistics game.I was late picking this one up and haven't followed all the early access drama, so I won't try to predict the probability of future updates, but there have been announcements of an imminent patch which will add Steam Workshop support, the ability to save and resume multiplayer sessions, and reworked multiplayer code that reduces bandwidth requirements many times over.  Whether the horrendous map UI, winch UI, camera and such ever get fixed or not I find this to be a game well worth trying.8.5/10, amazing

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Do you know what a locker is? Does the term 'UAZ' mean anything to you? Did you try recent 'off-road' 'sims' such as Off-Road Drive, then sigh and go back to Screamer 4x4? If you answered yes to the above then this game is for you!The terrain deformation that put this game on everyone's radar a few years back is still present, and the world doesn't just reset after you leave the area or even reload the game! Repeatedly take the same route through a soft paddock and you'll soon be fetching a support vehicle or left scratching your head whilst staring at an overturned log truck. It's challenging alright, even on the 'casual' setting, but it's also a lot of fun and very rewarding when you get things right.The visuals are incredible considering the relatively low specs required - with max settings I'm getting 60FPS @ 1920x1200 on a 3.6GHz i5, GTX460 and 4GB RAM. The lighting is stunning and it actually gets properly dark at night, which is all too rare in games.Like most games though it is far from perfect--The camera is great...until you try to move it. It feels like it was designed by Satan himself and is easily the worst part of the game-Controller support needs work. Can't configure buttons and you need to keep KB&M handy for important things like map navigation and using truck mechanisms (eg- winches). The use of analog triggers is also poorly implemented and trucks jump to about 50% throttle at the slightest press.-There is only autosaving and it only saves when you go to the main menu or quit. This means if the game crashes you can lose hours of progress, and you also can't have multiple simultaneous games going.-At time of writing, no mod supportIf you can see your way past the above then you could have a lot of fun with this game. Definitely worth the $30.

content:

												This game is an oddity it has no right to be this good . The idea of a game where the environment is trying to do you in should not work . Yet I love it . There are a billion and one tear round like a fool driving games but this is something new . You have to drive slowly and face it the trucks dont move that fast even when you do try lol . Add the winch mechanics to get you out of a jam which you will frequently and you have a really enjoyable game that gives you a real sense of achievemnt when you end up with a truck wedged in and either winch your way out or bring in another truck to help . Brains are needed to get anywhere with this . It isnt perfect the cloaked areas you have to drive to the exact centre of can be a nightmare to get to and there is next to no documentation on how to do things . No in truck view and an external camera thats twitchy as hell but yet its still a great game . The devs are still polishing and adding to it so it will only get better . In Soviet Russia even the mud hates you !

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Fantastic off road simulation. Gorgeous wilderness, impressive mud physics, and the vehicles have a great sense of mass and power with the way they handle. It's one of those games where there are goals, but the game doesn't hold your hand or guide you. It's up to you to set objectives, choose your paths and get it done. It can be frustrating considering the pace you have to take in order to avoid mishaps, but it's worth a look if you want to drive huge Soviet-era trucks through Crytech-rendered forests.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												*I play with a Logitech G27 Wheel and have only played singleplayer (so far)*I love this game. I don't really know why, but I do. I'm not a gear head or car guy by any means, but I got crazy into a racing game that led to me buying a G27 wheel. All I end up playing is Spintires though! I'm hooked. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, but it gives you all the pieces to do what you want. Beyond the objective of delivering lumber there is no right or wrong way to play Spintires, just your way. A playthrough of a map consists of some basic concepts;-You start with certain vehicle(s) at a checkpoint of a “garage”. Vehicles can take damage and they burn fuel that needs refilling.-A garage lets you change the attachments your vehicle has. In general they are attachments to carry garage parts, repair parts, log carriers, or fuel. But each vehicle's attachment options vary.-Each map has other garage locations that can be unlocked by delivering garage parts. Fueling stations for refueling vehicles and fuel carrying attachments. Lumber pickup areas where lumber has been cut down. And finally the objective areas where you are suppose to deliver the lumber to.And that's it. It's a simple game. You have to pickup and deliver a few loads of logs to one or more specified locations on a map. Simple! But... Not actually so simple. The terrain will make that a monumental undertaking. Mud mud and more mud! Hills, rocks, woods, raging rivers, open water, and more all are there to ruin your vehicle and day. It isn't a matter of IF you will get stuck or rollover its a matter of WHEN. And if it isn't the environs that get you, it'll be yourself. Progress is very slow and steady and can lull you in to a false sense of security. An hour or two of mistake free trudging in first gear and you get lazy and you make a mistake. A bad  turn, hit an object, try to cut a corner or cross a river at the wrong spot, take on deeper mud than you should with a heavier load, etc etc. You'll make mistakes no doubt. Throw in some strategic planning with which vehicles(s) you use for what and some side objectives/exploring... And you got yourself buried neck deep in the mud both literally and figuratively! But you aren't on your own out there. The vehicles and their attachments keep you movin'. And with winches on every vehicle as long as you're near some trees or can get a second vehicle close you got a chance to get unstuck or right-side-up again. I am constantly amazed at what I can get myself in to, and out of, in this game. And boy is there so so so many ways to get stuck, but just as many inventive ways to get out. "Where there's a will there's a way". You can spend hours just getting out of a mess you could have avoided in the first place. But somehow you end up not caring. As of writing this review I have completed 4 of the (currently) 6 stock maps on “hardcore” and they've taken me 3.5 to 6hrs a piece thanks to the messes you invariably get in to. Pros:-Difficult but completely fair.-A million mistakes to make and a million ways out of each one.-Runs at 60fps 1080p 100% of the time on my FX 6300/R9 270 toaster.-Fun as *blank* with G27!Things you will have to overcome:-The difficulty and your patience.-The camera angles seem annoying and “wrong” at first but ultimately make sense for the visual information you need when trudging through the mud. And you get used to them quickly. But the optional mouse movement to swing the camera around is fairly clunky. Also no “cockpit” camera as of writing this which means using a wheel in “third person” 99% of the time. There is a “hood” camera for tight corners. But like I said, the default view ultimately makes sense in the end. You see everything you NEED to from that angle, especially the tires' positions. -!!!Using a racing wheel like the G27 will not absolve you from still needing to use the mouse (and possibly keyboard)!!! Not all controls can be bound within the game but I used the Logitech Profiler software to bind keystrokes to buttons to eliminate my need for the keyboard 100%. There are crane controls for loading logs in “hardcore” mode that needs 9 buttons on its own. Without doing it my way you would still need to control that crane on the keyboard as well as some other controls. Then mouse will control menus, winch hookup placement, and manual looking around no matter what. So you WILL need your mouse no matter what. Not an issue with my desk setup but I know some people have “cockpits” for their wheels that don't accommodate a mouse and keyboard. So fair warning there!Cons:-Saving system is so-so. Its automatic and works fine. But twice I had save files corrupt when I Windows-key'd to minimize then re-maximized. Nothing tragic but the potential is there with how grueling a map can be. I can't imagine being 4hrs in and losing a save. I'd cry. And some on the forums have complained of losing in progress saves when the game has updated. I haven't needed it, but saves are in C:/Users/”your username”/AppDate/Roaming/SpinTires/UserSaves and if I exit in the middle of a long game I manually backup the file somewhere out of fear. But I have never had to use my backup. -Weird community. I guess there was lots promised for the game that the long time players still want. But there was a long stall in the updates or something. Then the current updates aren't coming fast enough for the community or something. You'll notice a lot of the “negative” reviews are people that actually like the game but are mad with the developers. Its unfair of me to judge being a fresh face but the community has been pure cynicism and impatience in my experiences so far. Which has kept me from prodding towards MP.The game is a great unique experience and words cannot explain it. I can't imagine keyboard and mouse controls being that much less of a great experience as a wheel. Because the game is just plain fun. But again this review is written by someone using a wheel. Which has been a great experience. The regular price is a bit steep but there are sales to be had. I personally got it in a bundle and that was an absolute steal. As of writing this the game is still being updated and worked on by the developer which is nice, always appreciate more! Supposedly Steam Workshop is coming which would be pretty neat. I guess a mod community already exists out on the web. Also, the MP looks like loads and loads of fun as well. But the stock, vanilla game is keeping me plenty busy for now and makes the game worth it on it's own. I am not a modern multitasker but this game lends itself well to watching TV/movies during it. Or having a phone/Skype convo during it. Very casual and methodical. But like I mentioned, don't get too distracted and lulled in to that false sense of security... You'll be spinning tires in the mud and cursing the heavens in no time! Enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												If you think you will like this game, you probably will. Many people complain about the mud being "too deep" and how the trucks react according to the enviroment, but they must not understand how large the trucks really are. Most of the hauling trucks surpass 6 tons easily, and are over 7 feet in height, if you don't believe me, search Russian loggingg trucks and just look.Anyways, onto the review.This game is really a peice of work, made by 2 people in Britian it takes place in Russia where you trade your time to deliver loads of logs to various objectives on 6 maps (more to come!). There is currently 2 gamemodes to choose from, casual and hardcore, both varying in features. In casual you can rescue trucks to a garage, in hardcore you cannot. Gas use in casual is little to none, in hardcore, you better have a fuel truck handy. Multiplayer is supported for 4-players at the time, and works best with people you know and can use a VoIP service with.Some counter-arguements for peoples dislikes:Camera: I honestly think the camera is part of the experience. And the views are some what odd, but you can toggle free view and lock it to where you like by clicking, and reset it by pressing "1". Could use some work, but if this is making you not buy the game, then your an a**hat.Price: Yes, the $30 price can seem a bit steep, but I think you can seriously enjoy the game with your friends. I put in 8 hours the first day I got this game, and I do not regret it at all. You seriously can get sucked into this logging enviroment.No 1st Person View: Seriously, is this keeping you from buying this?! Don't be such a panzy. Surely you have played a game with no 1st person view before, and it was just fine (GTA sound familiar). Like I said, don't be a panzy.All-in-all, the game is really going well for less than 2 months on Steam, and being developed by 2 people, it's really just amazing to see this. Do yourself a favor, buy the game, and don't be a panzy because there is no 1st person view, or something stupid of the sort.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Took the plunge and was not disappointed! This is pretty much the best true off-road simulator you'll find but bear in mind its NOT A RACING GAME. Speed is not the name of the game here but rather realistic navigation of a deep Russian forest! You've got mud, pools/streams/rivers/oceans of water, steep inclines, dried out riverbeds, dense forests, sharp switchbacks up a mountain side... a good variety of terrain.The game is incredibly simple in its objectives but its just plain fun to set out on a new map and find the best routes to load up and then deliver loads of lumber. Yes, thats the current way to "beat" the maps - you need to load lumber either with a crane or by going to specific lumber yards and loading up on short, medium or long logs and then hauling them across the map to drop points. AND THE PHYSICS! Damn, best mud and water physics I've seen for a driving game. Your tires will dig massive ruts, water has realistic currents and will flow even between your tires... its amazing. Where there was once a pristine trail could become a muddy hell at the end of the map after you've hauled heavy loads through it. As for the vehicles you've got an assortment of Russian trucks such as an old dually, a recon jeep and then you can even get up to massive 8x8 rolling fortresses that can only be stopped by the worst mud pits imaginable. Speaking of that recon jeep, each map starts out cloaked in black swirls/clouds that prevent you from seeing all the map right away. The cloaks can be removed simply by moving near them but they are often hidden away in deep forest/rough terrain and its pretty fun to scout out the unkown with your trusty jeep and reveal the map!The devs totally plan on supporting the game into the future and will be surely adding new trucks, maps and even new objectives/features so this already simple but fun game will become even greater with time!

												What can I say, big trucks, muddy roads, winches,  hauling logs...very cool game.  Camera is wonky at times but once you get used to it and moving it around its not too bad. would be cool if there were weather effects, snow, rain etc.  multiplayer is  pretty good though a proximity microphone chat feature would be good when traveling in a caravan, you cant type and drive at the same time. Happy truckin'.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												A bit rough around the edges but with some tweaks and changes can be the perfect off-road simulator.GRAPHICSThe world looks excelent and reflects well onto your vehicle such as mud being kicked up or being washed off with water and the effects on your vehicle are just as detailed and beautiful like the plumes of desel smoke coming out of exhausts and across the ground.Unfortunatly the same cannot be said for other players vehicles which lack any effects visible (or audible as there is no sound from other players vehicles) to you and also do not share terrain deformation which leaves them feeling more like ghosts in your world rather than active participants.The lighting in the game is a mixed bag. Normally its very well done but at night the world is far to bright except when you turn on your headlights which changes the lighting completely and makes the night feel much more realistic but sadly as other players headlights do not effect your game its left to be a mainly cinematic option as turning them on only cripples your vision.The water in the game is well worth mentioning as it looks amazing and makes the world feel much more alive.Weather effects freshen up extended time play in the game by varying the conditions of the world but unfortunatly they seem to have no impact on the world which is a huge missed oppertunity and a rain effect is blindingly missing.GAMEPLAYThis game is the closest experience to real world 4WDing I know of and its a joy to simply traverse the maps in the multiple vehicles provided but one of the most infuriating problems with the game is that most of the ground is far too slushy and appears deceptivly solid on observation.Areas that should without a doubt be solid ground, such as around trees and on high ground, can inexplainably be as liquidy as water, which gives an unwelcome randomness to the game and leads to traversing neccesary areas using only your winch, from tree to tree.Winches being as required as they are are inexplicably limited in length and more often than not when truly needed lack the length required to be used or used effectivly and are also limited in that you can only have one winch deployed at a time.Vehicles also lack appropriate winch points to recover them after rolling over so unless you play in the casual mode that allows automatic vehicle recovery you will need to spend up to an hour or so trying to get your vehicle right side up.Water features become incredably difficult to traverse when you are faced with not only extremely unpredictable ground, and no way to check water depth but also water currants far too unrealisticly strong and the overly dangerous water itself as when water reaches a certain height on your vehicle it will start to take huge chunks of damage and eventually cripple your vehicle.The camera (while currently being addressed) uses an AI that is absolutely horrible and will constantly make changes to your view that are more often than not extremely unappreciated and with no way to lock the cameras position you will not only be battling the terrain but battling the camera to show you what you need to see.There Isn't enough content in the game at launch with only a handfull of vehicles and appreciated but limited customization options for each.The game needs more variety, especially in the lower size of vehicles aswell as vehicles that promote interaction with other players and with the world itself.There is no variation in the objectives in the different maps which is another of the games great missed oppertunities where the game is expressly directed at the transportation of lumber to the exclusion of all else save for fuel and repair vehicles which facilitate the lumber transport.The damage system in the game stands next to the watery mud as one of the most unrealistic and annoyingly broken mechanics in the game as an subtle bounce along an otherwise prestine road can severely damage your truck and hitting unimportant parts of your truck without much force also eats away at your damage threshold very quickly in trucks without much ground clearance.Unfortunatly there is a lack of mod support for the game at launch but hopefully full mod support and steam workshop support will be implemented.MULTIPLAYServer hosts lack any options to customize the map and would greatly benifit from being able to edit the types of vehicles at each vehicle location, an option to remove cloaking and the ability to kick and ban players from their game.There are many other key features missing such as muting players, VoIP support, a chat log, saving progress for players during a hosts session, transfering host duties when a host leaves a game, a drop in drop out connection.The chatbox also dissapears randomly and pressing keys to type a message will sometimes trigger their bound action in the game.Players have next to no interaction with each other except for fullfilling objectives such as revealing cloaking.Towing players is near useless as the physics engine makes the experience jerky and feel extremely heavy compared to towing your own vehicles.Other players vehicles are strangly still somewhat interact with your unoccupied vehicles through physics while able to move through them and not see your unoccupied vehicles while not being effected by them at all.Unoccupied vehicles need to either be visible and interactive with other players or non interactive and not visible to other players.VirdictThe game is alot of fun and with the right support can become the best off-road sim currently available. Definitly worth the purchase if you want to experience off-roading at home.

Posted: June 16, 2014
												I was a supporter early on in the Kickstarter, the technology really interested me and I was excited to play around with it. Upon release I was pleasantly surprised to see that there was stuff to do! Fired it up, played around a bit, then immediately hopped into a coop with a couple friends. Before we knew it, 4 hours had passed. Lots of fun, some problem solving when you get stuck (or, even better, coop problem solving when your friend comes by to pull you out).Be aware it isn't an action game, and won't get by solely on the cool tech. If you enjoy logistical simulators, you'll like this one. If that sounds awful to you, maybe check out some YouTube videos before hand. Actually, do that either way. Smart consumerism and all that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												If you're interested solely in the idea of driving offroad through fairly realistic mud/water/rocks then this game does that very well.  It's not realistic to the point of being punishing but it does a good job of staying very far away from being arcade and it's satisfying to watch the simulated mud moving around as you drive through it.As for the rest of the game...it's more of a tech demo...you can load logs onto a truck from 1 or 2 log locations on the map and deliver them elsewhere to complete an achievement...you can take a trailer load of 'garage' parts to 1 or 2 spare garage locations on a map to unlock them(this is where you repair and get fuel trailers/change tires/change equipment on the trucks such as the crane attachment)....and you can offroad to "cloaking" places that obscure your map view in the beginning.  Outside of those few tasks the rest of the content has to come from you....maybe you got stuck and switch to another truck to come winch yourself out....maybe you broke a truck or need fuel so you grab yet another truck to bring repair points/fuel to yourself.....or maybe you drove through the same spot a few times and now the ruts have made you stuck.  Things can be a bit more fun if you have a friend or two(not random people) to play multiplayer with so you can convoy around together.  Over all the maps seem to be a bit small at roughly 3kmx3km(can take a while crawling in mud) and the lack of any additional missions or non-player AI means the game really does feel like a tech demo and given the terrible relations the devs have with the community I bet it'll stay like a tech demo.........BUT that doesn't stop me from recommending it to anybody that wants to do some offroading from the comfort of their home.

												So, I haven't had this for very long, but it is hilariously fun.. I spent the first 30 mins in a truck rolled over on it's side trying to figure out how to use the physics properly to winch myself back up again..The environments are really well done and thought out, and how the land reacts to your vehicle really makes you think about how you're going to tackle the terrain. Visually there has been some tremendous effort put in to make sure the environments are immersive, even the smallest puddles react accordingly to the vehicles..The single player, I can forsee it getting repetitive after the inital charm of the game wears out.. All in all, this is something that's original and surprisingly well thought out for what is it..Don't forget your Diff Lock 8/10.. Wook.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I absolutely love this game but it's not for everyone. Its essentially a simulator, but the physics are actually great unlike most simulators. The goal is essentially to pick up and deliver loads of lumber. But theres map to reveal, garages to unlock by delivering supplies, and repair and gas trailers to service your trucks (which you will need to do). Theres lots of (functional) customization to do and each truck has its own options. Including having a fully controllable crane!The game mechanics include deforming mud. So as roads are driven on the roads will degrade visibly as you leave your ruts in your wake. Trucks have lockable differentials and all wheel drive for when you need to get through the really tough terrain, which is most of the time. Trucks that are carrying loads feel considerably heavier than empty trucks. The physics are just awesome. My gf laughs at me but I swear, I've been driving down a rough road at about 3mph, and I've been literally on the edge of my seat because I'm afraid I'm going to tip the truck and lose my load after a long trek.If you enjoy Ice Road Truckers or watching Bonecrusher drive the muddy Maine logging roads in American Loggers, or you just love trucks like me then you're going to enjoy this game.My one complaint, and I am not alone in this, is the camera. It is pretty unweildy but I got mostly used to it. But there are times that you just can't get the view you need. The developers claim they are going to fix this in an update but that hasn't happened yet at the time I'm writing this.Other than that, the game delivers exactly what they say and they do it well. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												So,I just want to state that the first thing I did was to play multiplayer, and it was within the first 10 minutes of playing the game, that I learnt just how far a soft suspension truck is supposed to tilt.I roll to the bottom of a hill, on my roof, helpless with a stalled engine, and no idea how to get out of the situation I had just created.  Laughing at the same time at how I could go and♥♥♥♥♥♥up so fast.Anyway, I do what anyone would do, I hit every key looking for the chat button, "Ah, it's Y", I think to myself.  I then proceeded to plead to my comrades to save me!In the effort to save me, my friend Crevarski gets pulled over the edge of the hill and ends up stuck at the bottom of it, ensnared by all the surrounding stones deeper in the pit.This was, as you might assume, was unbelievably hilarious.We then both proceed to beg for the random player to save us.In his attempts to save us, he is then also pulled off the cliff, just to roll onto his roof on top of me.This led to tears of laughter on my end.Within the first 10 minutes, I knew my money was well invested, just because I've never laughed so much at having a lack of understanding the game.  The game is just hilarious as you go from blunder to blunder, stalling engines in every possible way possible for the first few hours.Once you're past that part of the game, and you start getting good at traversing the environment in your behemoths, it occurs to you that 1 truck is not going to cut it when tackling this unforgiving terrain!  Leading you to try and get a team sorted, where you'll have to assign everyone a task.  Such as 2 log haulers, and the other 2 as the support, dealing in the winching, repairing and refueling!(For those of you that don't enjoy multiplayer, you can switch to any truck unlocked at any time to go and save the one you just drowned in 'quick-mud')Anyway, this game is so unbelievably addictive, not just for the strangely addictive gameplay, but for the amount of teamwork that is required for a driving simulator, that even the 'crème de la crème' of driving games manage to skim the surface of.Plus, with the game being relatively new, I will ignore its minor flaws, such as the camera being annoying at times, and a few missing options that would of been nice, but aren't exactly going to ruin your time, as I'm sure most of these annoyances will be addressed very soon!I would DEFINITELY recommend this game to anyone that is interested in off-roading 'AND' games like Euro Truck Simulator.8.5/10

												Now Spintires is a strange game, when my friend tried to convince me to buy it and play it with him i thought "wtf man, you want me to play a lkw simulation in the sowjet pumpa ?" but after giving in to his naging we started playing it.Pro:-easy to learn-a lot of little tension moments (where you just pray that ur truck doesn't fall over etc.)-not too easy, not too hard on casual-there is a hardcore difficulty level-nice graphics-the trucks look realy good-KOOP-Mode is the best thing ever-saving urself from beeing stuck by using the wench can be quite challenging at times ;PCon:-as of now there are only 6 maps (but they play realy differently)-some things should be serverbased but are programmed client based (no seeing empty cars of other players, light of other cars)-no horn for the carsSo let me tell you, if you can get at least 1 friend to play this with you and you like challenging, skill- and witbased gameplay and don't dislike the old sowjet nomansland feel than this is deffinitly something for you.Else just w8 for a sale (summersale is active right now :D)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is an oddity it has no right to be this good . The idea of a game where the environment is trying to do you in should not work . Yet I love it . There are a billion and one tear round like a fool driving games but this is something new . You have to drive slowly and face it the trucks dont move that fast even when you do try lol . Add the winch mechanics to get you out of a jam which you will frequently and you have a really enjoyable game that gives you a real sense of achievemnt when you end up with a truck wedged in and either winch your way out or bring in another truck to help . Brains are needed to get anywhere with this . It isnt perfect the cloaked areas you have to drive to the exact centre of can be a nightmare to get to and there is next to no documentation on how to do things . No in truck view and an external camera thats twitchy as hell but yet its still a great game . The devs are still polishing and adding to it so it will only get better . In Soviet Russia even the mud hates you !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												I should start off by saying that for all it's faults, I've found Spintires to be a very fun game. However it does have it's faults, for me the most annoying fault that exists in the current version of the game (one that has existed since the first Tech Demo) is the camera. It isn't the worst camera ever in a game, but with the camera forced off the the right hand side, avoiding objects on your left side can be a pain. Hopefully a camera option for the left side and a centered camera will be added at some point.Another fault of the game is it's damage system. Some of the vehicles get damaged far too quickly, for example the Kamaz (the orange one) takes damage just driving through mud or over dirt, and all vehicles take damage when a pine tree brushes their side mirrors. While taking damage in this way is very rarely crippling, it adds up over time and makes little sense when you're being penalized for what are at best cosmetic scratches.Finally the save system (or lack of one) the game only allows you to have one map saved at a time and if you switch maps it erases your save on the old one, hopefully this is resolved soon.Now for the positives. The game has a fantastic vehicle physics engine with each vehicle feeling very good to drive, the terrain system with it's mud and water simulation works very well and the game looks very good visually. The Winch/Towing System works well and allows you to get out of some sticky situations without reseting your vehicle. Multiplayer exists though I haven't played it so I don't know how it works.All in all I very much enjoy the game, though your mileage may vary. Might not be worth the asking price for you.My rating 7/10 (pretty good)

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												I can't even really explain why I love this game so much. Friends that I try to describe it to invariably end up looking at me like I'm on crack. "So you just deliver logs?" - yes - but it's so much more than that. You're going to get stuck, you're going to run out of gas, you might even get swept down river. That's not the end of the story though. If you're stuck in some mud,  hook your winch to a tree and pull yourself out. If you're out of gas, grab a tanker truck and fill it back up. Even if your truck is totally submerged in water there's a pretty good chance you can just grab another truck and pull that bish out. It's muddy, gritty fun with a surprising amount of replayability and that's coming from someone with the attention span of a caffeinated squirrel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Do you know what a locker is? Does the term 'UAZ' mean anything to you? Did you try recent 'off-road' 'sims' such as Off-Road Drive, then sigh and go back to Screamer 4x4? If you answered yes to the above then this game is for you!The terrain deformation that put this game on everyone's radar a few years back is still present, and the world doesn't just reset after you leave the area or even reload the game! Repeatedly take the same route through a soft paddock and you'll soon be fetching a support vehicle or left scratching your head whilst staring at an overturned log truck. It's challenging alright, even on the 'casual' setting, but it's also a lot of fun and very rewarding when you get things right.The visuals are incredible considering the relatively low specs required - with max settings I'm getting 60FPS @ 1920x1200 on a 3.6GHz i5, GTX460 and 4GB RAM. The lighting is stunning and it actually gets properly dark at night, which is all too rare in games.Like most games though it is far from perfect--The camera is great...until you try to move it. It feels like it was designed by Satan himself and is easily the worst part of the game-Controller support needs work. Can't configure buttons and you need to keep KB&M handy for important things like map navigation and using truck mechanisms (eg- winches). The use of analog triggers is also poorly implemented and trucks jump to about 50% throttle at the slightest press.-There is only autosaving and it only saves when you go to the main menu or quit. This means if the game crashes you can lose hours of progress, and you also can't have multiple simultaneous games going.-At time of writing, no mod supportIf you can see your way past the above then you could have a lot of fun with this game. Definitely worth the $30.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												When I first saw videos for Spintires back when it was Early Access I assumed this was similar to the Farming Simulator 2015 games that you just drive farm equipment around and do meaningless tasks.  Then when I read that the point of the game is to drive around and haul logs I thought "this game can't be that fun..."It turns out after purchasing it I found myself stuck playing it for a few hours at a time.  Something about driving big, dirty, smoke-bellowing, diesel trucks through mud is entertaining.  The trucks look amazing, and there are some crash physics for when you rub against a tree or a large rock and watch the bumpers bend permanantly.  The mud and water physics aren't perfect, but they look absolutely amazing for a video game.  Sometimes it feels like you are watching a video of an actual truck.The lighting can be goofy and I find it's defintely easier to drive in the dark with the headlights off than with them on, which limits the view to only the cone in front of you.  But for as generic as the gameplay seems, it definately keeps you entertained for a while.My first time trying multiplayer mode was a complete blast.  Having to help tow your friends out of a mud bog was hilariously fun.  I have many screen shots of flipped over trucks with my friends' names hoving above them.The game is still a work in progress, but I have thouroughly enjoyed my purchase of this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Well, it's only been about 11+ hours or so; that's about 3-4 complete levels so far, either on Multiplayer or singleplayer.Personally, I like a simulator that makes it a challenge. If you wanted to play an off-road driving "Simulator" and hoped it would be and easy, fun-filled experience of bouncy bumper-cars in a sloppy muddy all-terrain wonderland.Well...Tough♥♥♥♥♥♥It's going to be difficult, it's going to be frustrating, but kinda funny to see your friends buried 3-4 feet under-mud/water/dirt/rivers...It's all about team-work, looking towards finishing your goals and achieving the objective. TO TRANSPORT LUMBER!!!Hopefully that was dramatic enough. Because it's not all that exciting. I'll give it that, there's my first con on this game; one objective...But that's fine, because the game doesn't have to end if you don't let it. Just drive around, explore the environment, laugh at mistakes and help each other out when in a jam.For example, every time my friend and I would go out, we'd split off to uncover the map, when that's all done, we'd recover the vehicles we needed and followed suite to each objective. one behind the other, so if one got stuck, the other could just pull him right out of the mud or a river.It was a lot of trial and error to figure out that layout. But all these guys that complain about the terrain being too hard, They are out of their minds. It is so easy to handle, if you know how to drive. :P and the camera controls are not bogus. People are just bad at controlling it. Press 1 to view the front and the back, press 2 to look at the trailer (If you have one) good to make sure you don't Jackknife or roll yourself over.And you can zoom in and out with the scroll wheel. Spin the mouse around when not in the advanced menu through V and you can get every angle possible around your vehicle. It's that simple. Pan And Zoom!So really, bottom line. Get This Game, NOW!It a lot of fun, you just have to let it happen and forgive yourself for any mistakes that you might happen along the way. I mean, Its just a game. right?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Spintires is an absolutely unique game. In a world where people want to race in amazing cars or have RPG-esque progression unlocks for their driving simulators, it instead presents an alternative style of gameplay. What you do is deliver garage and log points to objectives, but that is more of a framework for the game which can be completely ignored. The game is about mudding, obviously. If you haven't been mudding, you may not "get it." Unfortunately, it's one hell of an expensive hobby, so this is a great alternative. If you haven't had the experience of it, you may fail to realize that parts of the game that seem annoying or tedious are actually good times. Getting stuck in the mud is fun. Unsticking yourself is even more fun. Unsticking another person's truck because you're a better driver is the best. Breaking your truck slamming into a tree because you wanted to slalom down a hill at top speed is also fun, as is rolling off a hill with switchbacks on it. Delivering logs and garage points is alright too, I guess.The real crux of it is this: the game had a rough spell in development and the team they have on this is too small. It's a wonderful game with mods aplenty for the people who this style of game will appeal to. They need to prove themselves by finishing this game out (small amount of development effort still needed) before they can start on Spintires 2 or another team with a bigger budget will jump on it and create a spiritual successor. If it meets your price point and you're reading these reviews, you're invested enough you might consider getting it. For everyone else, let's see where this new subgenre will go before you throw money at it. It may ruin you for anything that ought to have mud that doesn't though, it makes those games feel like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 90s arcade style racers or so barebones you can't enjoy them anymore. The GTA and Farm Simulator series feel like they run a physics engine from two decades ago after playing this and it's physics are pretty bad.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Fantastic off road simulation. Gorgeous wilderness, impressive mud physics, and the vehicles have a great sense of mass and power with the way they handle. It's one of those games where there are goals, but the game doesn't hold your hand or guide you. It's up to you to set objectives, choose your paths and get it done. It can be frustrating considering the pace you have to take in order to avoid mishaps, but it's worth a look if you want to drive huge Soviet-era trucks through Crytech-rendered forests.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												*I play with a Logitech G27 Wheel and have only played singleplayer (so far)*I love this game. I don't really know why, but I do. I'm not a gear head or car guy by any means, but I got crazy into a racing game that led to me buying a G27 wheel. All I end up playing is Spintires though! I'm hooked. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, but it gives you all the pieces to do what you want. Beyond the objective of delivering lumber there is no right or wrong way to play Spintires, just your way. A playthrough of a map consists of some basic concepts;-You start with certain vehicle(s) at a checkpoint of a “garage”. Vehicles can take damage and they burn fuel that needs refilling.-A garage lets you change the attachments your vehicle has. In general they are attachments to carry garage parts, repair parts, log carriers, or fuel. But each vehicle's attachment options vary.-Each map has other garage locations that can be unlocked by delivering garage parts. Fueling stations for refueling vehicles and fuel carrying attachments. Lumber pickup areas where lumber has been cut down. And finally the objective areas where you are suppose to deliver the lumber to.And that's it. It's a simple game. You have to pickup and deliver a few loads of logs to one or more specified locations on a map. Simple! But... Not actually so simple. The terrain will make that a monumental undertaking. Mud mud and more mud! Hills, rocks, woods, raging rivers, open water, and more all are there to ruin your vehicle and day. It isn't a matter of IF you will get stuck or rollover its a matter of WHEN. And if it isn't the environs that get you, it'll be yourself. Progress is very slow and steady and can lull you in to a false sense of security. An hour or two of mistake free trudging in first gear and you get lazy and you make a mistake. A bad  turn, hit an object, try to cut a corner or cross a river at the wrong spot, take on deeper mud than you should with a heavier load, etc etc. You'll make mistakes no doubt. Throw in some strategic planning with which vehicles(s) you use for what and some side objectives/exploring... And you got yourself buried neck deep in the mud both literally and figuratively! But you aren't on your own out there. The vehicles and their attachments keep you movin'. And with winches on every vehicle as long as you're near some trees or can get a second vehicle close you got a chance to get unstuck or right-side-up again. I am constantly amazed at what I can get myself in to, and out of, in this game. And boy is there so so so many ways to get stuck, but just as many inventive ways to get out. "Where there's a will there's a way". You can spend hours just getting out of a mess you could have avoided in the first place. But somehow you end up not caring. As of writing this review I have completed 4 of the (currently) 6 stock maps on “hardcore” and they've taken me 3.5 to 6hrs a piece thanks to the messes you invariably get in to. Pros:-Difficult but completely fair.-A million mistakes to make and a million ways out of each one.-Runs at 60fps 1080p 100% of the time on my FX 6300/R9 270 toaster.-Fun as *blank* with G27!Things you will have to overcome:-The difficulty and your patience.-The camera angles seem annoying and “wrong” at first but ultimately make sense for the visual information you need when trudging through the mud. And you get used to them quickly. But the optional mouse movement to swing the camera around is fairly clunky. Also no “cockpit” camera as of writing this which means using a wheel in “third person” 99% of the time. There is a “hood” camera for tight corners. But like I said, the default view ultimately makes sense in the end. You see everything you NEED to from that angle, especially the tires' positions. -!!!Using a racing wheel like the G27 will not absolve you from still needing to use the mouse (and possibly keyboard)!!! Not all controls can be bound within the game but I used the Logitech Profiler software to bind keystrokes to buttons to eliminate my need for the keyboard 100%. There are crane controls for loading logs in “hardcore” mode that needs 9 buttons on its own. Without doing it my way you would still need to control that crane on the keyboard as well as some other controls. Then mouse will control menus, winch hookup placement, and manual looking around no matter what. So you WILL need your mouse no matter what. Not an issue with my desk setup but I know some people have “cockpits” for their wheels that don't accommodate a mouse and keyboard. So fair warning there!Cons:-Saving system is so-so. Its automatic and works fine. But twice I had save files corrupt when I Windows-key'd to minimize then re-maximized. Nothing tragic but the potential is there with how grueling a map can be. I can't imagine being 4hrs in and losing a save. I'd cry. And some on the forums have complained of losing in progress saves when the game has updated. I haven't needed it, but saves are in C:/Users/”your username”/AppDate/Roaming/SpinTires/UserSaves and if I exit in the middle of a long game I manually backup the file somewhere out of fear. But I have never had to use my backup. -Weird community. I guess there was lots promised for the game that the long time players still want. But there was a long stall in the updates or something. Then the current updates aren't coming fast enough for the community or something. You'll notice a lot of the “negative” reviews are people that actually like the game but are mad with the developers. Its unfair of me to judge being a fresh face but the community has been pure cynicism and impatience in my experiences so far. Which has kept me from prodding towards MP.The game is a great unique experience and words cannot explain it. I can't imagine keyboard and mouse controls being that much less of a great experience as a wheel. Because the game is just plain fun. But again this review is written by someone using a wheel. Which has been a great experience. The regular price is a bit steep but there are sales to be had. I personally got it in a bundle and that was an absolute steal. As of writing this the game is still being updated and worked on by the developer which is nice, always appreciate more! Supposedly Steam Workshop is coming which would be pretty neat. I guess a mod community already exists out on the web. Also, the MP looks like loads and loads of fun as well. But the stock, vanilla game is keeping me plenty busy for now and makes the game worth it on it's own. I am not a modern multitasker but this game lends itself well to watching TV/movies during it. Or having a phone/Skype convo during it. Very casual and methodical. But like I mentioned, don't get too distracted and lulled in to that false sense of security... You'll be spinning tires in the mud and cursing the heavens in no time! Enjoy!

Posted: March 2, 2016
												So at the time I originally posted this review, it had been because of issues with the game's source code that rendered it unplayable.  According to some people, this was a result of a dispute between the game's developer and its publisher, while the dev claimed it was tied into an anti-piracy system he'd implemented.  So if anyone who commented or anything wanted a reason for me switching it from not recommended to recommended, there you go.Whichever of those was true, that issue's been patched.  Instead, I can now say that Spintires is a genuinely fun game, particularly if you've got other people playing it with you.  There isn't really anything else like this out there, that I've seen, and I genuinely can't recommend it enough now that it's back up and running.
